Comment:
Hi everyone!

This is Round 4 against The Great One, GM Cyrano.  At the moment he is 4th seeded on Gameknot with his rating north of 2600!  Well, guys, I lose this one but at least I make Afro do a little work for it, albeit, I did tend to have a recurrence of passivitis which I cannot afford when playing the elite.  So, how did this game unravel.  Here is gameknot analysis as follows:- http://gameknot.com/analyze-board.pl?bd=17807983&fb=1&rnd=0.181263129796375

1. ...... e6 - oh, la, la!  I decided to kick off with the French Defense.  I played that against lighttotheright (Ken) many moons ago but got my butt whipped.  However, I decided it was time to resurrect my favourite riposte as black.

23. ...... axb5 - Afro gets rid of his weakie a pawn and I now have two weakie pawns, on the d column and the b column, giving Fou Leblanc a lot of work to do.  Fou Leblanc therefore becomes a "bad" bishop, tied to defending pawns on his own squares.

36. f4!! - this move prevents f4, sacrificing my f pawn so that I can get Fou Leblanc onto f5 protecting my vital g pawn.

36. .... Rg8?? This move was flagged as a blunder.  Gameknot Analysis suggested Rd7 shielding Henry from being checked on the second rank by the WR.  However, I noted that after Rb8, his rook could come round to h2 and inflict some damage.  However, after reading Gameknot Analysis search engine, I would have had drawing chances even though I would have been two pawns down.  Fou Leblanc would have protected the h and f pawns, and Henry may well have been able to stop the c passer and I would have had a rook that could move freely.  Ah well, you live and learn.

38. ...... Bc8 - this move does not cut the mustard as, although it prevents a Rb8+ skewer it does not prevent a Re7+ followed by either mate or loss of Fou Leblanc for starters by the Windmill.  I chose the more painless option .......
